title.raw: 《宋微子世家》 House of Song Wei Zi

sentences.zh: 微子開者，殷帝乙之首子而帝紂之庶兄也。

translations.literal: Wei Zi Kai was Emperor Yi of Yin's eldest son and Emperor Zhou's elder half-brother.
translations.idiomatic: Wei Zi Kai was the eldest son of Emperor Yi of Yin and the elder half-brother of Emperor Zhou.

sentences.zh: 紂既立，不明，淫亂於政，微子數諫，紂不聽。

translations.literal: Zhou was already established but unenlightened. He was licentious and chaotic in government. Wei Zi frequently admonished him, but Zhou would not listen.
translations.idiomatic: Once Zhou ascended the throne, he proved unenlightened. He indulged in licentiousness and created chaos in governance. Wei Zi frequently admonished him, but Zhou refused to listen.

sentences.zh: 及祖伊以周西伯昌之修德，滅黎國，懼禍至，以告紂。

translations.literal: And Zu Yi, because Zhou's Xi Bo Chang cultivated virtue and extinguished the Li state, feared calamity would arrive, so he told Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: When Zu Yi saw that Zhou's Xi Bo Chang was cultivating virtue and had extinguished the state of Li, he feared calamity was approaching and reported this to Zhou.

sentences.zh: 紂曰：「我生不有命在天乎？

translations.literal: Zhou said: 'I born not have fate in heaven?'
translations.idiomatic: Zhou said: 'Don't I have my fate in heaven?'

sentences.zh: 是何能為！」

translations.literal: This what can do!'
translations.idiomatic: What can this do!'

sentences.zh: 於是微子度紂終不可諫，欲死之，及去，未能自決，乃問於太師、少師曰：「殷不有治政，不治四方。

translations.literal: Then Wei Zi measured Zhou finally not admonishable, desired die for it, and go, not able self decide, then asked Tai Shi, Shao Shi said: 'Yin not have governing politics, not governing four directions.
translations.idiomatic: Then Wei Zi realized Zhou could finally not be admonished. He desired to die for it, and when he was about to leave, he could not decide for himself. He then asked the Tai Shi and Shao Shi, saying: 'Yin does not have governing politics, does not govern the four directions.

sentences.zh: 我祖遂陳於上，紂沈湎於酒，婦人是用，亂敗湯德於下。

translations.literal: My ancestor Sui displayed his virtue above. Zhou is immersed in wine and uses women, chaotically defeating Tang's virtue below.
translations.idiomatic: My ancestor Sui displayed his virtue above. Zhou is immersed in wine and employs women, chaotically destroying Tang's virtue below.

sentences.zh: 殷既小大好草竊姦宄，卿士師師非度，皆有罪辜，乃無維獲，小民乃并興，相為敵讎。

translations.literal: Yin already, from small to great, delights in bandits, thieves, wicked evildoers. The qing and shi shi shi not according to measure, all have crime and guilt. Then there is no support to obtain. The small people then all rise up together, becoming enemies and foes to each other.
translations.idiomatic: Yin, from the lowest to the highest, now delights in bandits, thieves, and wicked evildoers. The ministers and officials all act improperly and are guilty of crimes. There is no support to be found. The common people all rise up together, becoming enemies and foes to one another.

sentences.zh: 今殷其典喪！

translations.literal: Now Yin its rules lost!
translations.idiomatic: Now Yin has lost its rules!

sentences.zh: 若涉水無津涯。

translations.literal: Like fording water with no bank or shore.
translations.idiomatic: It is like fording a river with no ford or shore in sight.

sentences.zh: 殷遂喪，越至于今。」

translations.literal: Yin then perished, extend to now.'
translations.idiomatic: Yin has then perished, extending to the present.'

sentences.zh: 曰：「太師，少師，我其發出往？

translations.literal: Said: 'Tai Shi, Shao Shi, I should set out go?'
translations.idiomatic: He said: 'Tai Shi, Shao Shi, should I set out and go?'

sentences.zh: 吾家保于喪？

translations.literal: My family preserve in perished?'
translations.idiomatic: Should my family be preserved in the perished state?'

sentences.zh: 今女無故告予，顛躋，如之何其？」

translations.literal: Now you without reason tell me, fall stumble, like what how its?'
translations.idiomatic: Now you tell me without reason, falling and stumbling—what should I do about it?'

sentences.zh: 太師若曰：「王子，天篤下菑亡殷國，乃毋畏畏，不用老長。

translations.literal: Tai Shi Ruo said: 'Prince, heaven thickly down calamity perish Yin state, then not fear fear, not use elders.
translations.idiomatic: The Tai Shi Ruo said: 'Prince, heaven has thickly sent down calamity to perish the Yin state. Then do not fear fear, do not use the elders.

sentences.zh: 今殷民乃陋淫神祇之祀。

translations.literal: Now the Yin people are vulgar and licentiously sacrificing to the spirits.
translations.idiomatic: Now the Yin people are vulgar and licentiously sacrificing to the spirits and deities.

sentences.zh: 今誠得治國，國治身死不恨。

translations.literal: Now if I truly obtain to govern the state, govern the state and my body dies—I will not regret it.
translations.idiomatic: If I could truly obtain the governance of the state, and govern it well even if it costs me my life—I would have no regrets.

sentences.zh: 為死，終不得治，不如去。」

translations.literal: For death, finally not obtain govern, not as good go.'
translations.idiomatic: To die, and finally not obtain to govern—not as good as to go.'

sentences.zh: 遂亡。

translations.literal: He then fled.
translations.idiomatic: He then went into exile.

sentences.zh: 箕子者，紂親戚也。

translations.literal: Ji Zi was Zhou's relative.
translations.idiomatic: Ji Zi was a relative of Zhou.

sentences.zh: 紂始為象箸，箕子嘆曰：「彼為象箸，必為玉桮；

translations.literal: Zhou began make ivory chopsticks, Ji Zi sighed said: 'He make ivory chopsticks, must make jade cup;
translations.idiomatic: Zhou began to make ivory chopsticks. Ji Zi sighed and said: 'He makes ivory chopsticks, he must make jade cups;

sentences.zh: 為桮，則必思遠方珍怪之物而御之矣。

translations.literal: To make a cup, one must then think of precious and strange things from distant places and use them.
translations.idiomatic: To make a cup, one must seek out precious and exotic things from distant lands to adorn it.

sentences.zh: 輿馬宮室之漸自此始，不可振也。」

translations.literal: Chariot horse palace chamber gradual from this begin, cannot revive.'
translations.idiomatic: The gradual development of chariots, horses, palaces, and chambers begins from this. It cannot be revived.'

sentences.zh: 紂為淫泆，箕子諫，不聽。

translations.literal: Zhou committed licentious excesses. Ji Zi admonished him, but he would not listen.
translations.idiomatic: Zhou indulged in licentious excesses. Ji Zi admonished him, but he would not listen.

sentences.zh: 人或曰：「可以去矣。」

translations.literal: People or said: 'Can go.'
translations.idiomatic: Some people said: 'You can go.'

sentences.zh: 箕子曰：「為人臣諫不聽而去，是彰君之惡而自說於民，吾不忍為也。」

translations.literal: Ji Zi said: 'Be minister admonish not listen and go, is display lord evil and self please to people, I not endure do.'
translations.idiomatic: Ji Zi said: 'To be a minister, admonish but not be listened to and then go—this displays the lord's evil and pleases oneself to the people. I cannot bear to do this.'

sentences.zh: 乃被髪詳狂而為奴。

translations.literal: He then disheveled his hair, pretended to be mad, and became a slave.
translations.idiomatic: He then disheveled his hair, feigned madness, and became a slave.

sentences.zh: 遂隱而鼓琴以自悲，故傳之曰箕子操。

translations.literal: He then hid himself and played the zither to grieve for himself. Therefore it is transmitted as the Ji Zi Cao.
translations.idiomatic: He then went into hiding and played the zither to express his grief. Therefore it is transmitted as the 'Ji Zi Melody.'

sentences.zh: 王子比干者，亦紂之親戚也。

translations.literal: Prince Bi Gan was also Zhou's relative.
translations.idiomatic: Prince Bi Gan was also a relative of Zhou.

sentences.zh: 見箕子諫不聽而為奴，則曰：「君有過而不以死爭，則百姓何辜！」

translations.literal: Saw Ji Zi admonish not listen became slave, then said: 'Lord has error not with death contend, then hundred surnames what guilt!'
translations.idiomatic: He saw Ji Zi admonish but not be listened to and become a slave. He then said: 'If the lord has errors and one does not contend with death, then what guilt do the common people have!'

sentences.zh: 乃直言諫紂。

translations.literal: He then straightforwardly admonished Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: He then admonished Zhou with direct and frank words.

sentences.zh: 紂怒曰：「吾聞聖人之心有七竅，信有諸乎？」

translations.literal: Zhou angered said: 'I heard sage person heart has seven apertures, truly has it?'
translations.idiomatic: Zhou was angered and said: 'I heard that a sage person's heart has seven apertures. Is this truly so?'

sentences.zh: 乃遂殺王子比干，刳視其心。

translations.literal: He then killed Prince Bi Gan, cut him open, and viewed his heart.
translations.idiomatic: He then killed Prince Bi Gan, cut open his chest, and examined his heart.

sentences.zh: 微子曰：「父子有骨肉，而臣主以義屬。

translations.literal: Wei Zi said: 'Father son have bone flesh, minister lord with righteousness belong.
translations.idiomatic: Wei Zi said: 'Father and son have bone and flesh connections, while minister and lord belong through righteousness.

sentences.zh: 故父有過，子三諫不聽，則隨而號之；

translations.literal: Therefore father has error, son three admonish not listen, then follow cry for him;
translations.idiomatic: Therefore if a father has errors, a son admonishes three times but is not listened to, then he follows and cries for him;

sentences.zh: 人臣三諫不聽，則其義可以去矣。」

translations.literal: Minister three admonish not listen, then righteousness can go.'
translations.idiomatic: If a minister admonishes three times but is not listened to, then in righteousness he can leave.'

sentences.zh: 於是太師、少師乃勸微子去，遂行。

translations.literal: Then the Tai Shi and Shao Shi urged Wei Zi to go, and he then went.
translations.idiomatic: The Grand Tutor and Junior Tutor then urged Wei Zi to leave, and he departed.

sentences.zh: 周武王伐紂克殷，微子乃持其祭器造於軍門，肉袒面縛，左牽羊，右把茅，膝行而前以告。

translations.literal: Zhou's King Wu attacked Zhou and conquered Yin. Wei Zi then held his sacrificial vessels and went to the army gate, bare flesh and bound face, left hand leading a sheep, right hand grasping thatch, knee-walking forward to inform.
translations.idiomatic: When King Wu of Zhou attacked Zhou and conquered Yin, Wei Zi carried his ancestral sacrificial vessels and presented himself at the army gate. Bare-chested and with his face bound, leading a sheep in his left hand and holding thatch in his right, he crawled forward on his knees to surrender.

sentences.zh: 於是武王乃釋微子，復其位如故。

translations.literal: Then King Wu released Wei Zi and restored his position as before.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu then released Wei Zi and restored his former position.

sentences.zh: 武王封紂子武庚祿父以續殷祀，使管叔、蔡叔傅相之。

translations.literal: King Wu enfeoffed Zhou's son Wu Geng Lu Fu to continue the Yin sacrifices, and made Guan Shu and Cai Shu tutor and assist him.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu enfeoffed Zhou's son Wu Geng Lu Fu to continue the Yin ancestral sacrifices, and appointed Guan Shu and Cai Shu to tutor and assist him.

sentences.zh: 武王既克殷，訪問箕子。

translations.literal: King Wu had already conquered Yin and inquired of Ji Zi.
translations.idiomatic: After King Wu had conquered Yin, he sought out and consulted Ji Zi.

sentences.zh: 武王曰：「於乎！

translations.literal: Wu Wang said: 'Alas!'
translations.idiomatic: King Wu said: 'Alas!'

sentences.zh: 維天陰定下民，相和其居，我不知其常倫所序。」

translations.literal: Only heaven secretly settles lower people, mutually harmonize their residence, I not know its constant order where arranged.'
translations.idiomatic: Only heaven secretly settles the lower people, mutually harmonizing their residences. I do not know where its constant order is arranged.'

sentences.zh: 箕子對曰：「在昔鯀陻鴻水，汨陳其五行，帝乃震怒，不從鴻範九等，常倫所斁。

translations.literal: Ji Zi replied said: 'In former times Gun dammed great water, confused displayed its five phases, Emperor then angrily shook, not followed great pattern nine grades, constant order where abandoned.
translations.idiomatic: Ji Zi replied, saying: 'In former times Gun dammed the great water and confusedly displayed its five phases. The Emperor then angrily shook and did not follow the great pattern's nine grades. The constant order was where it was abandoned.

sentences.zh: 鯀則殛死，禹乃嗣興。

translations.literal: Gun was then executed and died. Yu then succeeded and rose.
translations.idiomatic: Gun was then punished with death. Yu then succeeded him and rose to prominence.

sentences.zh: 天乃錫禹鴻範九等，常倫所序。

translations.literal: Heaven then granted Yu the great pattern's nine grades, where the constant order was arranged.
translations.idiomatic: Heaven then bestowed upon Yu the Great Plan's nine categories, by which the constant order of things is arranged.

sentences.zh: 「初一曰五行；

translations.literal: 'First one called five phases;
translations.idiomatic: 'The first is called the five phases;

sentences.zh: 二曰五事；

translations.literal: Second called five matters;
translations.idiomatic: The second is called the five matters;

sentences.zh: 三曰八政；

translations.literal: Third called eight governments;
translations.idiomatic: The third is called the eight governments;

sentences.zh: 四曰五紀；

translations.literal: Fourth called five records;
translations.idiomatic: The fourth is called the five records;

sentences.zh: 五曰皇極；

translations.literal: Fifth called royal pole;
translations.idiomatic: The fifth is called the royal pole;

sentences.zh: 六曰三德；

translations.literal: Sixth called three virtues;
translations.idiomatic: The sixth is called the three virtues;

sentences.zh: 七曰稽疑；

translations.literal: Seventh called examine doubts;
translations.idiomatic: The seventh is called examining doubts;

sentences.zh: 八曰庶徵；

translations.literal: Eighth called many signs;
translations.idiomatic: The eighth is called the many signs;

sentences.zh: 九曰嚮用五福，畏用六極。

translations.literal: The ninth is called facing using the five blessings, fearing using the six extremes.
translations.idiomatic: The ninth is called: Face the five blessings; fear the six extremes.

sentences.zh: 「五行：一曰水，二曰火，三曰木，四曰金，五曰土。

translations.literal: 'Five phases: one called water, two called fire, three called wood, four called metal, five called earth.
translations.idiomatic: 'The five phases: one is called water, two is called fire, three is called wood, four is called metal, five is called earth.

sentences.zh: 水曰潤下，火曰炎上，木曰曲直，金曰從革，土曰稼穡。

translations.literal: Water is called moistening downward. Fire is called flaming upward. Wood is called bending and straightening. Metal is called following change. Earth is called plowing and harvesting.
translations.idiomatic: Water's nature is to moisten downward. Fire's nature is to flame upward. Wood's nature is bending and straightening. Metal's nature is following change. Earth's nature is plowing and harvesting.

sentences.zh: 潤下作鹹，炎上作苦，曲直作酸，從革作辛，稼穡作甘。

translations.literal: Moistening downward makes salty. Flaming upward makes bitter. Bending and straightening makes sour. Following change makes pungent. Plowing and harvesting makes sweet.
translations.idiomatic: Moistening downward produces saltiness. Flaming upward produces bitterness. Bending and straightening produces sourness. Following change produces pungency. Plowing and harvesting produces sweetness.

sentences.zh: 「五事：一曰貌，二曰言，三曰視，四曰聽，五曰思。

translations.literal: 'Five matters: one called appearance, two called speech, three called seeing, four called hearing, five called thinking.
translations.idiomatic: 'The five matters: one is called appearance, two is called speech, three is called seeing, four is called hearing, five is called thinking.

sentences.zh: 貌曰恭，言曰從，視曰明，聽曰聰，思曰睿。

translations.literal: Appearance is called respectful. Speech is called compliant. Seeing is called clear. Hearing is called acute. Thinking is called profound.
translations.idiomatic: Appearance is called respectful. Speech is called compliant. Vision is called clear. Hearing is called acute. Thought is called profound.

sentences.zh: 恭作肅，從作治，明作智，聰作謀，睿作聖。

translations.literal: Respectful makes solemn. Compliant makes orderly. Clear makes wise. Acute makes plans. Profound makes sage.
translations.idiomatic: Respectfulness produces solemnity. Compliance produces order. Clarity produces wisdom. Acuteness produces strategy. Profundity produces sageliness.

sentences.zh: 「八政：一曰食，二曰貨，三曰祀，四曰司空，五曰司徒，六曰司寇，七曰賓，八曰師。

translations.literal: 'Eight governments: one called food, two called goods, three called sacrifices, four called Si Kong, five called Si Tu, six called Si Kou, seven called guests, eight called army.
translations.idiomatic: 'The eight governments: one is called food, two is called goods, three is called sacrifices, four is called Si Kong, five is called Si Tu, six is called Si Kou, seven is called guests, eight is called army.

sentences.zh: 「五紀：一曰歲，二曰月，三曰日，四曰星辰，五曰歷數。

translations.literal: 'Five records: one called year, two called month, three called day, four called stars planets, five called calendar numbers.
translations.idiomatic: 'The five records: one is called year, two is called month, three is called day, four is called stars and planets, five is called calendar numbers.

sentences.zh: 「皇極：皇建其有極，斂時五福，用傅錫其庶民，維時其庶民于女極，錫女保極。

translations.literal: 'Royal pole: king establishes his having pole, gathers timely five blessings, uses spread grant his common people, only then his common people at your pole, grant you preserve pole.
translations.idiomatic: 'The royal pole: the king establishes his having a pole, gathers the timely five blessings, uses them to spread and grant to his common people. Only then are his common people at your pole. Grant you to preserve the pole.

sentences.zh: 凡厥庶民，毋有淫朋，人毋有比德，維皇作極。

translations.literal: All their common people shall not have licentious companions. People shall not have comparable virtue. Only the king makes the pole.
translations.idiomatic: All the common people shall have no licentious companions. No person shall have virtue that matches another's. Only the sovereign establishes the standard.

sentences.zh: 凡厥庶民，有猷有為有守，女則念之。

translations.literal: All their common people who have plans, have actions, have holdings—you then think of them.
translations.idiomatic: All the common people who have plans, abilities, and integrity—you must keep them in mind.

sentences.zh: 不協于極，不離于咎，皇則受之。

translations.literal: Not agreeing at the pole, not separating at calamity—the king then accepts it.
translations.idiomatic: If they do not conform to the standard and persist in wrongdoing, the sovereign must accept responsibility.

sentences.zh: 而安而色，曰予所好德，女則錫之福。

translations.literal: Their peaceful appearance—said 'I what good virtue'—you then grant them blessings.
translations.idiomatic: When they appear peaceful and content, saying 'I love virtuous conduct,' then you should bestow blessings upon them.

sentences.zh: 時人斯其維皇之極。

translations.literal: Timely people—this is their only wang pole.
translations.idiomatic: Such timely people—this is the sovereign's only standard.

sentences.zh: 毋侮寡而畏高明。

translations.literal: Do not insult the few and fear the high and bright.
translations.idiomatic: Do not bully the weak nor fear the powerful and intelligent.

sentences.zh: 人之有能有為，使羞其行，而國其昌。

translations.literal: People who have ability and action—make them ashamed of their conduct, and the state will prosper.
translations.idiomatic: When people of ability and initiative feel ashamed of their conduct, the state will flourish.

sentences.zh: 凡厥正人，既富方穀。

translations.literal: All their upright people are already rich in each valley.
translations.idiomatic: All upright people are already wealthy in their various domains.

sentences.zh: 女不能使有好于而家，時人斯其辜。

translations.literal: You cannot make there be good in your family. Timely people—this is their crime.
translations.idiomatic: If you cannot bring goodness to your own family, then such timely people are guilty.

sentences.zh: 于其毋好，女雖錫之福，其作女用咎。

translations.literal: At their not being good, though you grant them blessings, they will make you use calamity.
translations.idiomatic: When they are not good, even if you bestow blessings upon them, they will bring calamity upon you.

sentences.zh: 毋偏毋頗，遵王之義。

translations.literal: Not partial, not inclined—follow the wang's righteousness.
translations.idiomatic: Be neither partial nor prejudiced—follow the sovereign's righteousness.

sentences.zh: 毋有作好，遵王之道。

translations.literal: Do not have making good—follow the wang's way.
translations.idiomatic: Do not create artificial goodness—follow the sovereign's way.

sentences.zh: 毋有作惡，遵王之路。

translations.literal: Do not have making evil—follow the wang's road.
translations.idiomatic: Do not create artificial evil—follow the sovereign's path.

sentences.zh: 毋偏毋黨，王道蕩蕩。

translations.literal: Not partial, not factional—the wang's way is broad and broad.
translations.idiomatic: Be neither partial nor cliquish—the sovereign's way is broad and expansive.

sentences.zh: 毋黨毋偏，王道平平。

translations.literal: Not factional, not partial—the wang's way is level and level.
translations.idiomatic: Be neither cliquish nor partial—the sovereign's way is level and fair.

sentences.zh: 毋反毋側，王道正直。

translations.literal: Not contrary, not slanted—the wang's way is straight and upright.
translations.idiomatic: Be neither contrary nor devious—the sovereign's way is straight and upright.

sentences.zh: 會其有極，歸其有極。

translations.literal: Gather their having a pole. Return their having a pole.
translations.idiomatic: Gather those who have standards. Return those who have standards.

sentences.zh: 曰王極之傅言，是夷是訓，于帝其順。

translations.literal: The wang pole's spread words—this is even, this is instruction. To the emperor it is compliant.
translations.idiomatic: The sovereign's standard teachings—these are fair and instructive. To the emperor they are compliant.

sentences.zh: 凡厥庶民，極之傅言，是順是行，以近天子之光。

translations.literal: All their common people—the pole's spread words—this is compliant, this is action, to approach the Tian Zi's light.
translations.idiomatic: All the common people—the standard's teachings—these they comply with and act upon, to draw near the Son of Heaven's radiance.

sentences.zh: 曰天子作民父母，以為天下王。

translations.literal: It is said the Tian Zi makes himself the people's parents, to be the wang of the world.
translations.idiomatic: It is said that the Son of Heaven acts as parent to the people, to be the sovereign of all under heaven.

sentences.zh: 「三德：一曰正直，二曰剛克，三曰柔克。

translations.literal: 'Three virtues: one called upright straight, two called firm overcome, three called gentle overcome.
translations.idiomatic: 'The three virtues: one is called upright and straight, two is called firm overcoming, three is called gentle overcoming.

sentences.zh: 平康正直，彊不友剛克，內友柔克，沈漸剛克，高明柔克。

translations.literal: Peace and calm are upright and straight. Strong but not friendly uses firm overcoming. Inner friendly uses gentle overcoming. Deep and gradual uses firm overcoming. High and bright uses gentle overcoming.
translations.idiomatic: Peace and tranquility are upright and straight. The strong but unsociable are overcome by firmness. The inwardly friendly are overcome by gentleness. The deep and gradual are overcome by firmness. The high and brilliant are overcome by gentleness.

sentences.zh: 維辟作福，維辟作威，維辟玉食。

translations.literal: Only the ruler makes blessings. Only the ruler makes awe. Only the ruler has jade food.
translations.idiomatic: Only the ruler bestows blessings. Only the ruler inspires awe. Only the ruler enjoys jade-adorned banquets.

sentences.zh: 臣無有作福作威玉食。

translations.literal: Ministers shall not have making blessings, making awe, jade food.
translations.idiomatic: Ministers shall not bestow blessings, inspire awe, nor enjoy jade-adorned banquets.

sentences.zh: 臣有作福作威玉食，其害于而家，凶于而國，人用側頗辟，民用僭忒。

translations.literal: If ministers have making blessings, making awe, jade food—it harms your family, is calamitous for your state. People use slanted and inclined rulers. People use presumptuous and deviant ways.
translations.idiomatic: If ministers bestow blessings, inspire awe, or enjoy jade-adorned banquets—it harms your family and brings calamity to your state. People will follow crooked and perverse rulers. The people will adopt presumptuous and deviant ways.

sentences.zh: 「稽疑：擇建立卜筮人。

translations.literal: 'Examine doubts: select establish divination people.
translations.idiomatic: 'Examining doubts: select and establish divination people.

sentences.zh: 乃命卜筮，曰雨，曰濟，曰涕，曰霧，曰克，曰貞，曰悔，凡七。

translations.literal: Then command divination: called rain, called aid, called tear, called fog, called overcome, called upright, called regret—altogether seven.
translations.idiomatic: Then command divination by turtle and milfoil: called rain, called aid, called tears, called fog, called victory, called uprightness, called regret—in all seven.

sentences.zh: 卜五，占之用二，衍貣。

translations.literal: Divine five times, use two for the divination, extend greedily.
translations.idiomatic: Divine five times, but use only two for the interpretation, extending it greedily.

sentences.zh: 立時人為卜筮，三人占則從二人之言。

translations.literal: Establish timely people as divination, three people divine then follow two people's words.
translations.idiomatic: Establish timely people as diviners. When three people divine, then follow two people's words.

sentences.zh: 女則有大疑，謀及女心，謀及卿士，謀及庶人，謀及卜筮。

translations.literal: You then have great doubt—plan reaching your heart, plan reaching the qing shi, plan reaching the common people, plan reaching divination.
translations.idiomatic: When you have grave doubts, consult your own heart, consult the nobles, consult the common people, and consult the divination.

sentences.zh: 女則從，龜從，筮從，卿士從，庶民從，是之謂大同，而身其康彊，而子孫其逢吉。

translations.literal: You then follow, turtle follows, divination follows, qing shi follow, common people follow—this is called great unity, and your body will be peaceful and strong, and your descendants will meet with auspiciousness.
translations.idiomatic: If you follow, and the tortoise-shell agrees, the divination agrees, the nobles agree, and the common people agree—this is called great harmony. Your person will be peaceful and strong, and your descendants will encounter good fortune.

sentences.zh: 女則從，龜從，筮從，卿士逆，庶民逆，吉。

translations.literal: You then follow, turtle follows, divination follows, qing shi are contrary, common people are contrary—auspicious.
translations.idiomatic: If you follow, the tortoise-shell agrees, the divination agrees, but the nobles oppose and the common people oppose—it is still auspicious.

sentences.zh: 卿士從，龜從，筮從，女則逆，庶民逆，吉。

translations.literal: Qing shi follow, turtle follows, divination follows, you are contrary, common people are contrary—auspicious.
translations.idiomatic: If the nobles agree, the tortoise-shell agrees, the divination agrees, but you oppose and the common people oppose—it is still auspicious.

sentences.zh: 庶民從，龜從，筮從，女則逆，卿士逆，吉。

translations.literal: Common people follow, turtle follows, divination follows, you are contrary, qing shi are contrary—auspicious.
translations.idiomatic: If the common people agree, the tortoise-shell agrees, the divination agrees, but you oppose and the nobles oppose—it is still auspicious.

sentences.zh: 女則從，龜從，筮逆，卿士逆，庶民逆，作內吉，作外凶。

translations.literal: You then follow, turtle follows, divination is contrary, qing shi are contrary, common people are contrary—making inner affairs auspicious, making outer affairs inauspicious.
translations.idiomatic: You then follow, the turtle follows, but divination is contrary, the nobles are contrary, the common people are contrary—auspicious for inner affairs, inauspicious for outer affairs.

sentences.zh: 龜筮共違于人，用靜吉，用作凶。

translations.literal: Turtle and divination together contrary to people—using quiet is auspicious, using action is inauspicious.
translations.idiomatic: When both turtle and milfoil contradict the people—using stillness is auspicious, using action is inauspicious.

sentences.zh: 「庶徵：曰雨，曰陽，曰奧，曰寒，曰風，曰時。

translations.literal: 'Many signs: called rain, called sunshine, called warm, called cold, called wind, called season.
translations.idiomatic: 'The many signs: called rain, called sunshine, called warm, called cold, called wind, called season.

sentences.zh: 五者來備，各以其序，庶草繁廡。

translations.literal: The five come prepared, each in their order, and many grasses are luxuriant and full.
translations.idiomatic: When all five come prepared, each in its proper order, then the many grasses flourish abundantly.

sentences.zh: 一極備，凶。

translations.literal: One extreme prepared—inauspicious.
translations.idiomatic: When only one extreme is prepared—inauspicious.

sentences.zh: 一極亡，凶。

translations.literal: One extreme gone—inauspicious.
translations.idiomatic: When one extreme is missing—inauspicious.

sentences.zh: 曰休徵：曰肅，時雨若，曰治，時暘若；

translations.literal: Called auspicious signs: called solemn, timely rain like, called orderly, timely sunshine like;
translations.idiomatic: Called auspicious signs: called solemn, timely rain as it should be, called orderly, timely sunshine as it should be;

sentences.zh: 曰知，時奧若；

translations.literal: Called wisdom, timely warm like;
translations.idiomatic: Called wisdom, timely warmth as it should be;

sentences.zh: 曰謀，時寒若；

translations.literal: Called planning, timely cold like;
translations.idiomatic: Called planning, timely cold as it should be;

sentences.zh: 曰聖，時風若。

translations.literal: Called sage, timely wind as it should be.
translations.idiomatic: It is called sagehood: the timely winds blow as they should.

sentences.zh: 曰咎徵：曰狂，常雨若；

translations.literal: Called calamitous signs: called madness, constant rain like;
translations.idiomatic: Called calamitous signs: called madness, constant rain as it should be;

sentences.zh: 曰僭，常暘若；

translations.literal: Called usurpation, constant sunshine like;
translations.idiomatic: Called usurpation, constant sunshine as it should be;

sentences.zh: 曰舒，常奧若；

translations.literal: Called laxity, constant warm like;
translations.idiomatic: Called laxity, constant warmth as it should be;

sentences.zh: 曰急，常寒若；

translations.literal: Called urgency, constant cold like;
translations.idiomatic: Called urgency, constant cold as it should be;

sentences.zh: 曰霧，常風若。

translations.literal: Called fog, constant wind as it should be.
translations.idiomatic: It is called fog: the constant winds blow as they should.

sentences.zh: 王眚維歲，卿士維月，師尹維日。

translations.literal: The wang's blemish affects only the year. The qing shi affects only the month. The shi yin affects only the day.
translations.idiomatic: The sovereign's faults affect only the year. The ministers' faults affect only the month. The officials' faults affect only the day.

sentences.zh: 歲月日時毋易，百穀用成，治用明，畯民用章，家用平康。

translations.literal: Year, month, day, season do not change. The hundred grains mature. Governance is clear. Good people are manifest. Families are peaceful and healthy.
translations.idiomatic: When years, months, days, and seasons do not deviate, the hundred grains ripen. Governance is enlightened. Worthy people are manifest. Families are peaceful and prosperous.

sentences.zh: 日月歲時既易，百穀用不成，治用昏不明，畯民用微，家用不寧。

translations.literal: Day, month, year, season have already changed. The hundred grains do not mature. Governance is dark and not clear. Good people are subtle. Families are not peaceful.
translations.idiomatic: When days, months, years, and seasons deviate from their proper course, the hundred grains fail to ripen. Governance becomes dark and unclear. Worthy people remain obscure. Families are troubled and restless.

sentences.zh: 庶民維星，星有好風，星有好雨。

translations.literal: The common people are only stars. Stars have good wind. Stars have good rain.
translations.idiomatic: The common people are like the stars. The stars bring favorable winds. The stars bring favorable rains.

sentences.zh: 日月之行，有冬有夏。

translations.literal: The movement of sun and moon has winter and has summer.
translations.idiomatic: The courses of sun and moon bring winter and summer.

sentences.zh: 月之從星，則以風雨。

translations.literal: When the moon follows the stars, it then brings wind and rain.
translations.idiomatic: When the moon follows the stars, it brings wind and rain.

sentences.zh: 「五福：一曰壽，二曰富，三曰康寧，四曰攸好德，五曰考終命。

translations.literal: 'Five blessings: one called longevity, two called wealth, three called peaceful healthy, four called practice good virtue, five called examine end life.
translations.idiomatic: 'The five blessings: one is called longevity, two is called wealth, three is called peaceful and healthy, four is called practicing good virtue, five is called examining the end of life.

sentences.zh: 六極：一曰凶短折，二曰疾，三曰憂，四曰貧，五曰惡，六曰弱。」

translations.literal: Six extremes: one called inauspicious short broken, two called illness, three called worry, four called poverty, five called evil, six called weak.'
translations.idiomatic: The six extremes: one is called inauspicious and short broken, two is called illness, three is called worry, four is called poverty, five is called evil, six is called weak.'

sentences.zh: 於是武王乃封箕子於朝鮮而不臣也。

translations.literal: Then King Wu enfeoffed Ji Zi at Joseon and did not make him a vassal.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu then enfeoffed Ji Zi in Joseon without requiring him to serve as a vassal.

sentences.zh: 其後箕子朝周，過故殷虛，感宮室毀壞，生禾黍，箕子傷之，欲哭則不可，欲泣為其近婦人，乃作麥秀之詩以歌詠之。

translations.literal: After that, Ji Zi paid court to Zhou. He passed the former Yin ruins, felt the palace chambers were destroyed and broken, growing wheat and millet. Ji Zi grieved for it. He desired to cry but it was not permissible. He desired to weep but it was because he was near women. He then made the 'Mai Xiu' poem to sing and chant it.
translations.idiomatic: Afterward, Ji Zi went to pay court to Zhou. Passing through the former Yin capital, he was moved by the ruined palaces overgrown with wheat and millet. Ji Zi grieved deeply. He wanted to cry out but it was not proper. He wanted to weep but refrained because women were nearby. So he composed the poem 'Wheat Ears' to express his lament through song.

sentences.zh: 其詩曰：「麥秀漸漸兮，禾黍油油。

translations.literal: Its poem said: 'Wheat ear gradually gradually, millet grain oily oily.
translations.idiomatic: The poem said: 'The wheat ears gradually, the millet grains oily.

sentences.zh: 彼狡僮兮，不與我好兮！」

translations.literal: That crafty boy, not with me good!'
translations.idiomatic: That crafty boy does not treat me well!'

sentences.zh: 所謂狡童者，紂也。

translations.literal: What was called the crafty boy was Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: The so-called 'crafty boy' was Zhou.

sentences.zh: 殷民聞之，皆為流涕。

translations.literal: The Yin people heard it and all shed streaming tears.
translations.idiomatic: When the Yin people heard this, they all wept bitterly.

sentences.zh: 武王崩，成王少，周公旦代行政當國。

translations.literal: King Wu died. King Cheng was young. The Duke of Zhou Dan substituted and administered the government, holding the state.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu passed away. King Cheng was still young, so the Duke of Zhou Dan acted as regent and governed the realm.

sentences.zh: 管、蔡疑之，乃與武庚作亂，欲襲成王、周公。

translations.literal: Guan and Cai doubted it. They then made rebellion with Wu Geng, desiring to attack King Cheng and the Duke of Zhou.
translations.idiomatic: The Dukes of Guan and Cai grew suspicious and, together with Wu Geng, rebelled in an attempt to assassinate King Cheng and the Duke of Zhou.

sentences.zh: 周公既承成王命誅武庚，殺管叔，放蔡叔，乃命微子開代殷後，奉其先祀，作微子之命以申之，國于宋。

translations.literal: The Duke of Zhou had already received King Cheng's command to execute Wu Geng, kill Guan Shu, and banish Cai Shu. He then commanded Wei Zi Kai to replace the Yin descendants, offer their ancestor sacrifices, made the Wei Zi command to repeat it, and established the state at Song.
translations.idiomatic: Having received King Cheng's command, the Duke of Zhou executed Wu Geng, put Guan Shu to death, and banished Cai Shu. He then appointed Wei Zi Kai to succeed the Yin line, maintain their ancestral sacrifices, issued the Wei Zi Decree to confirm this, and established the state of Song.

sentences.zh: 微子故能仁賢，乃代武庚，故殷之餘民甚戴愛之。

translations.literal: Wei Zi was therefore able to be benevolent and worthy. He then replaced Wu Geng. Therefore Yin's remnant people greatly revered and loved him.
translations.idiomatic: Wei Zi was renowned for his benevolence and virtue. He succeeded Wu Geng as ruler. Therefore, the surviving Yin people greatly revered and loved him.

sentences.zh: 釐公十七年，周厲王出奔彘。

translations.literal: In Duke Xi's seventeenth year, King Li of Zhou fled to Zhi.
translations.idiomatic: In the seventeenth year of Duke Xi, King Li of Zhou fled to the region of Zhi.

sentences.zh: 二十八年，釐公卒，子惠公覵立。

translations.literal: In the twenty-eighth year, Duke Xi died, and his son Duke Hui Bi ascended.
translations.idiomatic: In the twenty-eighth year, Duke Xi passed away, and his son Duke Hui Bi ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 惠公四年，周宣王即位。

translations.literal: In Duke Hui's fourth year, King Xuan of Zhou ascended the throne.
translations.idiomatic: In the fourth year of Duke Hui, King Xuan of Zhou ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 三十年，惠公卒，子哀公立。

translations.literal: In the thirtieth year, Duke Hui died, and his son Duke Ai ascended.
translations.idiomatic: In the thirtieth year, Duke Hui passed away, and his son Duke Ai succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 哀公元年卒，子戴公立。

translations.literal: Duke Ai died in his first year, and his son Duke Dai ascended.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Ai died in his first year of rule, and his son Duke Dai ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 戴公二十九年，周幽王為犬戎所殺，秦始列為諸侯。

translations.literal: In Duke Dai's twenty-ninth year, King You of Zhou was killed by the Quan Rong. Qin began to be ranked as feudal lords.
translations.idiomatic: In the twenty-ninth year of Duke Dai, King You of Zhou was killed by the Quanrong barbarians. Qin was first elevated to the rank of feudal lord.

sentences.zh: 三十四年，戴公卒，子武公司空立。

translations.literal: In the thirty-fourth year, Duke Dai died, and his son Duke Wu Si Kong ascended.
translations.idiomatic: In the thirty-fourth year, Duke Dai passed away, and his son Duke Wu Si Kong ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 武公生女為魯惠公夫人，生魯桓公。

translations.literal: Duke Wu gave birth to a daughter who became Duke Hui of Lu's wife. She gave birth to Duke Huan of Lu.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Wu had a daughter who became the wife of Duke Hui of Lu. She gave birth to Duke Huan of Lu.

sentences.zh: 十八年，武公卒，子宣公力立。

translations.literal: In the eighteenth year, Duke Wu died, and his son Duke Xuan Li ascended.
translations.idiomatic: In the eighteenth year, Duke Wu passed away, and his son Duke Xuan Li ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 宣公有太子與夷。

translations.literal: Duke Xuan had a crown prince named Yu Yi.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Xuan had a crown prince named Yu Yi.

sentences.zh: 十九年，宣公病，讓其弟和，曰：「父死子繼，兄死弟及，天下通義也。

translations.literal: Nineteenth year, Xuan Gong ill, yielded his younger brother He, said: 'Father dies son succeeds, elder brother dies younger brother reaches, world common righteousness.
translations.idiomatic: In the nineteenth year, Duke Xuan was ill. He yielded to his younger brother He, saying: 'Father dies, son succeeds. Elder brother dies, younger brother reaches. This is the world's common righteousness.

sentences.zh: 我其立和。」

translations.literal: I should establish He.'
translations.idiomatic: I should establish He as ruler.'

sentences.zh: 和亦三讓而受之。

translations.literal: He also yielded three times, then accepted it.
translations.idiomatic: He also declined three times before accepting.

sentences.zh: 宣公卒，弟和立，是為穆公。

translations.literal: Duke Xuan died. His younger brother He ascended, who became Duke Mu.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Xuan passed away. His younger brother He ascended the throne and became Duke Mu.

sentences.zh: 穆公九年，病，召大司馬孔父謂曰：「先君宣公捨太子與夷而立我，我不敢忘。

translations.literal: Mu Gong ninth year, ill, summoned grand si ma Kong Fu told said: 'Former lord Xuan Gong abandoned crown prince Yu Yi established me, I dare not forget.
translations.idiomatic: In Duke Mu's ninth year, he was ill. He summoned Grand Si Ma Kong Fu and told him: 'The former lord Duke Xuan abandoned Crown Prince Yu Yi and established me. I dare not forget.

sentences.zh: 我死，必立與夷也。」

translations.literal: I die, must establish Yu Yi.'
translations.idiomatic: When I die, you must establish Yu Yi.'

sentences.zh: 孔父曰：「群臣皆願立公子馮。」

translations.literal: Kong Fu said: 'Multitude ministers all wish establish prince Ping.'
translations.idiomatic: Kong Fu said: 'All the ministers wish to establish Prince Ping.'

sentences.zh: 穆公曰：「毋立馮，吾不可以負宣公。」

translations.literal: Mu Gong said: 'Do not establish Ping, I cannot betray Xuan Gong.'
translations.idiomatic: Duke Mu said: 'Do not establish Ping. I cannot betray Duke Xuan.'

sentences.zh: 於是穆公使馮出居于鄭。

translations.literal: Then Duke Mu made Ping exit and reside at Zheng.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Mu then sent Ping into exile to reside in the state of Zheng.

sentences.zh: 八月庚辰，穆公卒，兄宣公子與夷立，是為殤公。

translations.literal: In the eighth month, Geng Chen, Duke Mu died. His elder brother Duke Xuan's son Yu Yi ascended, who became Duke Shang.
translations.idiomatic: On the Geng Chen day of the eighth month, Duke Mu passed away. His nephew Yu Yi, son of his elder brother Duke Xuan, ascended the throne and became Duke Shang.

sentences.zh: 君子聞之，曰：「宋宣公可謂知人矣，立其弟以成義，然卒其子復享之。

translations.literal: Gentleman heard it, said: 'Song Xuan Gong can be called knows people, established his younger brother to complete righteousness, yet finally his son again enjoyed it.
translations.idiomatic: The gentleman heard of it and said: 'Song's Duke Xuan can be called one who knows people. He established his younger brother to complete righteousness, yet in the end his son again enjoyed it.

sentences.zh: 莊公元年，華督為相。

translations.literal: In Duke Zhuang's first year, Hua Du served as prime minister.
translations.idiomatic: In the first year of Duke Zhuang, Hua Du became prime minister.

sentences.zh: 九年，執鄭之祭仲，要以立突為鄭君。

translations.literal: Ninth year, seized Zheng's Ji Zhong, coerced to establish Tu as Zheng lord.
translations.idiomatic: In the ninth year, he seized Zheng's Ji Zhong and coerced him to establish Tu as Zheng's lord.

sentences.zh: 祭仲許，竟立突。

translations.literal: Ji Zhong permitted it, and finally established Tu.
translations.idiomatic: Ji Zhong agreed, and in the end established Tu as ruler.

sentences.zh: 十九年，莊公卒，子湣公捷立。

translations.literal: In the nineteenth year, Duke Zhuang died, and his son Duke Min Jie ascended.
translations.idiomatic: In the nineteenth year, Duke Zhuang passed away, and his son Duke Min Jie ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 十年夏，宋伐魯，戰於乘丘，魯生虜宋南宮萬。

translations.literal: In the tenth year summer, Song attacked Lu and battled at Cheng Qiu. Lu captured Song's Nan Gong Wan alive.
translations.idiomatic: In summer of the tenth year, Song invaded Lu and fought a battle at Cheng Qiu. Lu captured Nan Gong Wan of Song alive.

sentences.zh: 宋人請萬，萬歸宋。

translations.literal: The Song people requested Wan, and Wan returned to Song.
translations.idiomatic: The Song people requested Wan's return, and Wan went back to Song.

sentences.zh: 十一年秋，湣公與南宮萬獵，因博爭行，湣公怒，辱之，曰：「始吾敬若；

translations.literal: Eleventh year autumn, Min Gong with Nan Gong Wan hunted, because gambling contended route, Min Gong angered, humiliated him, said: 'Beginning I respected you;
translations.idiomatic: In the eleventh year autumn, Duke Min hunted with Nan Gong Wan. Because of gambling they contended over the route. Duke Min was angered and humiliated him, saying: 'At the beginning I respected you;

sentences.zh: 今若，魯虜也。」

translations.literal: Now you, Lu captive.'
translations.idiomatic: Now you are Lu's captive.'

sentences.zh: 萬有力，病此言，遂以局殺湣公于蒙澤。

translations.literal: Wan had strength and resented these words. He then used a chessboard to kill Duke Min at Meng Ze.
translations.idiomatic: Wan was strong and resented these words. He then used a game board to bludgeon Duke Min to death at Meng Ze.

sentences.zh: 大夫仇牧聞之，以兵造公門。

translations.literal: Grand officer Qiu Mu heard of it and went to the gong's gate with troops.
translations.idiomatic: The grand officer Qiu Mu heard of this and rushed to the duke's gate with armed men.

sentences.zh: 萬搏牧，牧齒著門闔死。

translations.literal: Wan wrestled with Mu. Mu's teeth bit the gate latch and he died.
translations.idiomatic: Wan grappled with Mu. Mu's teeth clamped onto the gate latch as he died.

sentences.zh: 因殺太宰華督，乃更立公子游為君。

translations.literal: He then killed Grand Steward Hua Du, and changed to establish Prince You as lord.
translations.idiomatic: He then killed the Grand Steward Hua Du and installed Prince You as the new ruler.

sentences.zh: 諸公子奔蕭，公子御說奔亳。

translations.literal: The various princes fled to Xiao. Prince Yu Yue fled to Bo.
translations.idiomatic: The various princes fled to Xiao. Prince Yu Yue fled to Bo.

sentences.zh: 萬弟南宮牛將兵圍亳。

translations.literal: Wan's younger brother Nan Gong Niu led troops and surrounded Bo.
translations.idiomatic: Wan's younger brother Nan Gong Niu led troops and besieged Bo.

sentences.zh: 冬，蕭及宋之諸公子共擊殺南宮牛，弒宋新君游而立湣公弟御說，是為桓公。

translations.literal: In winter, Xiao and Song's various princes together struck and killed Nan Gong Niu, assassinated Song's new lord You, and established Duke Min's younger brother Yu Yue, who became Duke Huan.
translations.idiomatic: In winter, forces from Xiao together with Song's various princes attacked and killed Nan Gong Niu, assassinated the newly installed ruler You, and established Duke Min's younger brother Yu Yue as ruler, who became Duke Huan.

sentences.zh: 宋萬奔陳。

translations.literal: Song Wan fled to Chen.
translations.idiomatic: Song Wan fled to the state of Chen.

sentences.zh: 宋人請以賂陳。

translations.literal: The Song people requested with a bribe to Chen.
translations.idiomatic: The Song people requested Chen to hand him over in exchange for a bribe.

sentences.zh: 陳人使婦人飲之醇酒，以革裹之，歸宋。

translations.literal: The Chen people made a woman drink him pure wine, wrapped him in leather, and returned him to Song.
translations.idiomatic: The Chen people got a woman to ply him with strong wine until he was drunk, wrapped him in leather, and sent him back to Song.

sentences.zh: 宋人醢萬也。

translations.literal: The Song people minced Wan.
translations.idiomatic: The Song people executed Wan by mincing him into pieces.

sentences.zh: 襄公七年，宋地茀星如雨，與雨偕下；

translations.literal: Xiang Gong seventh year, Song earth fell stars like rain, with rain together descended;
translations.idiomatic: In Duke Xiang's seventh year, stars fell on Song's earth like rain, descending together with the rain;

sentences.zh: 六鶂退蜚，風疾也。

translations.literal: Six pheasants retreated and flew—the wind was violent.
translations.idiomatic: Six pheasants flew backward—the wind was fierce.

sentences.zh: 八年，齊桓公卒，宋欲為盟會。

translations.literal: In the eighth year, Duke Huan of Qi died. Song desired to make an alliance assembly.
translations.idiomatic: In the eighth year, Duke Huan of Qi passed away. Song wished to convene an alliance conference.

sentences.zh: 十二年春，宋襄公為鹿上之盟，以求諸侯於楚，楚人許之。

translations.literal: In the twelfth year spring, Duke Xiang of Song made the Lu Shang alliance to seek feudal lords from Chu. The Chu people permitted it.
translations.idiomatic: In spring of the twelfth year, Duke Xiang of Song convened the alliance at Lu Shang to seek recognition as leader of the feudal lords from Chu. The Chu people agreed.

sentences.zh: 公子目夷諫曰：「小國爭盟，禍也。」

translations.literal: Prince Mu Yi admonished said: 'Small state contends alliance, calamity.'
translations.idiomatic: Prince Mu Yi admonished, saying: 'A small state contending for alliances—calamity.'

sentences.zh: 不聽。

translations.literal: He did not listen.
translations.idiomatic: He refused to listen.

sentences.zh: 秋，諸侯會宋公盟于盂。

translations.literal: In autumn, the feudal lords assembled and Duke Song allied at Yu.
translations.idiomatic: In autumn, the feudal lords assembled and formed an alliance with Duke Xiang of Song at Yu.

sentences.zh: 目夷曰：「禍其在此乎？

translations.literal: Mu Yi said: 'Calamity perhaps here?'
translations.idiomatic: Mu Yi said: 'The calamity is perhaps here?'

translations.idiomatic: The lord's desire is already excessive. What can endure it!'

sentences.zh: 於是楚執宋襄公以伐宋。

translations.literal: Then Chu seized Duke Xiang of Song to attack Song.
translations.idiomatic: Chu then seized Duke Xiang of Song and used this as a pretext to attack Song.

sentences.zh: 冬，會于亳，以釋宋公。

translations.literal: In winter, they assembled at Bo to release Duke Song.
translations.idiomatic: In winter, they assembled at Bo to negotiate Duke Xiang's release.

sentences.zh: 子魚曰：「禍猶未也。」

translations.literal: Zi Yu said: 'Calamity still not yet.'
translations.idiomatic: Zi Yu said: 'The calamity is still not yet.'

sentences.zh: 十三年夏，宋伐鄭。

translations.literal: In the thirteenth year summer, Song attacked Zheng.
translations.idiomatic: In summer of the thirteenth year, Song attacked Zheng.

sentences.zh: 子魚曰：「禍在此矣。」

translations.literal: Zi Yu said: 'Calamity here.'
translations.idiomatic: Zi Yu said: 'The calamity is here.'

sentences.zh: 秋，楚伐宋以救鄭。

translations.literal: In autumn, Chu attacked Song to save Zheng.
translations.idiomatic: In autumn, Chu attacked Song to relieve Zheng.

sentences.zh: 襄公將戰，子魚諫曰：「天之棄商久矣，不可。」

translations.literal: Xiang Gong about to battle, Zi Yu admonished said: 'Heaven abandoned Shang long ago, not permissible.'
translations.idiomatic: Duke Xiang was about to battle. Zi Yu admonished, saying: 'Heaven abandoned Shang long ago. It is not permissible.'

sentences.zh: 冬，十一月，襄公與楚成王戰于泓。

translations.literal: In winter, eleventh month, Duke Xiang battled with King Cheng of Chu at Hong.
translations.idiomatic: In winter, in the eleventh month, Duke Xiang fought King Cheng of Chu at the Hong River.

sentences.zh: 楚人未濟，目夷曰：「彼眾我寡，及其未濟擊之。」

translations.literal: Chu people not yet crossed, Mu Yi said: 'They many we few, take advantage their not crossed strike them.'
translations.idiomatic: The Chu people had not yet crossed. Mu Yi said: 'They are many, we are few. Take advantage while they have not crossed to strike them.'

sentences.zh: 公不聽。

translations.literal: The gong did not listen.
translations.idiomatic: The duke refused to listen.

sentences.zh: 已濟未陳，又曰：「可擊。」

translations.literal: Already crossed not yet arrayed, again said: 'Can strike.'
translations.idiomatic: They had already crossed but not yet arrayed. He again said: 'Can strike.'

sentences.zh: 公曰：「待其已陳。」

translations.literal: Gong said: 'Wait their already arrayed.'
translations.idiomatic: The gong said: 'Wait until they are already arrayed.'

sentences.zh: 陳成，宋人擊之。

translations.literal: The array was completed. The Song people struck them.
translations.idiomatic: Once the enemy formation was complete, the Song forces attacked.

sentences.zh: 宋師大敗，襄公傷股。

translations.literal: The Song army was greatly defeated. Duke Xiang was wounded in the thigh.
translations.idiomatic: The Song army suffered a crushing defeat. Duke Xiang was wounded in the thigh.

sentences.zh: 國人皆怨公。

translations.literal: The state people all resented the gong.
translations.idiomatic: The people of the state all resented the duke.

sentences.zh: 公曰：「君子不困人於阸，不鼓不成列。」

translations.literal: Gong said: 'Gentleman not distress people at narrow pass, not drum not formed ranks.'
translations.idiomatic: The gong said: 'A gentleman does not distress people at a narrow pass, does not drum when ranks are not formed.'

sentences.zh: 子魚曰：「兵以勝為功，何常言與！

translations.literal: Zi Yu said: 'Warriors with victory as merit, what constant words with!'
translations.idiomatic: Zi Yu said: 'Warriors take victory as merit. What constant words!'

sentences.zh: 必如公言，即奴事之耳，又何戰為？」

translations.literal: Must like gong speak, then slave serve them, again what battle for?'
translations.idiomatic: If must be like the gong says, then we slave serve them. What battle for?'

sentences.zh: 楚成王已救鄭，鄭享之；

translations.literal: Chu Cheng Wang already saved Zheng, Zheng feasted him;
translations.idiomatic: King Cheng of Chu had already saved Zheng. Zheng feasted him;

sentences.zh: 去而取鄭二姬以歸。

translations.literal: He left and took Zheng's two ji to return.
translations.idiomatic: He left but took Zheng's two princesses with him when he returned.

sentences.zh: 叔瞻曰：「成王無禮，其不沒乎？

translations.literal: Shu Zhan said: 'Cheng Wang without ritual, his not drown?'
translations.idiomatic: Shu Zhan said: 'King Cheng has no ritual. Will he not drown?'

sentences.zh: 為禮卒於無別，有以知其不遂霸也。」

translations.literal: Make ritual end at without distinction, have to know his not succeed hegemony.'
translations.idiomatic: He makes ritual end at having no distinction. There is reason to know he will not succeed in hegemony.'

sentences.zh: 是年，晉公子重耳過宋，襄公以傷於楚，欲得晉援，厚禮重耳以馬二十乘。

translations.literal: This year, Jin's Prince Chong Er passed through Song. Duke Xiang, because wounded by Chu, desired to obtain Jin's aid. He thickly ritualed Chong Er with twenty chariots of horses.
translations.idiomatic: That year, Prince Chong Er of Jin passed through Song. Duke Xiang, still wounded from his defeat by Chu, sought Jin's support and lavished Chong Er with gifts of twenty chariot teams of horses.

sentences.zh: 十四年夏，襄公病傷於泓而竟卒，子成公王臣立。

translations.literal: In the fourteenth year summer, Duke Xiang's illness from being wounded at Hong finally caused him to die. His son Duke Cheng Wang Chen ascended.
translations.idiomatic: In summer of the fourteenth year, Duke Xiang succumbed to the illness from his wound at the Hong River. His son Wang Chen ascended the throne as Duke Cheng.

sentences.zh: 十七年，成公卒。

translations.literal: In the seventeenth year, Duke Cheng died.
translations.idiomatic: In the seventeenth year, Duke Cheng passed away.

sentences.zh: 成公弟御殺太子及大司馬公孫固而自立為君。

translations.literal: Duke Cheng's younger brother Yu killed the crown prince and Grand Si Ma Gong Sun Gu and self-established as lord.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Cheng's younger brother Yu killed the crown prince and Grand Marshal Gong Sun Gu, then usurped the throne for himself.

sentences.zh: 宋人共殺君御而立成公少子杵臼，是為昭公。

translations.literal: The Song people together killed Lord Yu and established Duke Cheng's young son Chu Jiu, who became Duke Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: The people of Song united to kill Lord Yu and installed Duke Cheng's youngest son Chu Jiu as ruler, who became Duke Zhao.

sentences.zh: 九年，昭公無道，國人不附。

translations.literal: In the ninth year, Duke Zhao had no way. The state people were not attached.
translations.idiomatic: In the ninth year, Duke Zhao ruled tyrannically and lost the people's allegiance.

sentences.zh: 昭公弟鮑革賢而下士。

translations.literal: Duke Zhao's younger brother Bao Ge was worthy and lowered himself to scholars.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Zhao's younger brother Bao Ge was virtuous and treated scholars with respect.

sentences.zh: 先，襄公夫人欲通於公子鮑，不可，乃助之施於國，因大夫華元為右師。

translations.literal: Previously, Duke Xiang's wife desired to have relations with Prince Bao. It was not permissible, so she helped him distribute in the state and used Grand Officer Hua Yuan as right teacher.
translations.idiomatic: Earlier, Duke Xiang's wife had tried to seduce Prince Bao, but he rejected her. She then helped him gain influence in the state and used Grand Officer Hua Yuan as his ally.

sentences.zh: 昭公出獵，夫人王姬使衛伯攻殺昭公杵臼。

translations.literal: Duke Zhao went hunting. His wife Wang Ji made Wei Bo attack and kill Duke Zhao Chu Jiu.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Zhao went hunting. His wife Wang Ji sent Wei Bo to attack and assassinate Duke Zhao Chu Jiu.

sentences.zh: 弟鮑革立，是為文公。

translations.literal: His younger brother Bao Ge ascended, who became Duke Wen.
translations.idiomatic: His younger brother Bao Ge ascended the throne and became Duke Wen.

sentences.zh: 四年春，（鄭）［楚］命（楚）［鄭］伐宋。

translations.literal: In the fourth year spring, Zheng commanded Chu to attack Song.
translations.idiomatic: In spring of the fourth year, Zheng ordered Chu to attack Song.

sentences.zh: 宋使華元將，鄭敗宋，囚華元。

translations.literal: Song made Hua Yuan lead. Zheng defeated Song and imprisoned Hua Yuan.
translations.idiomatic: Song sent Hua Yuan to command their forces. Zheng defeated Song and took Hua Yuan prisoner.

sentences.zh: 華元之將戰，殺羊以食士，其御羊羹不及，故怨，馳入鄭軍，故宋師敗，得囚華元。

translations.literal: Hua Yuan was about to battle. He killed a sheep to feed the soldiers. His driver did not obtain mutton soup, so he resented it. He galloped into the Zheng army. Therefore the Song army was defeated, and they obtained and imprisoned Hua Yuan.
translations.idiomatic: As battle was about to begin, Hua Yuan slaughtered a sheep to feed his troops. His charioteer was denied mutton stew, so he nursed a grudge. During the fighting, he deliberately charged into the Zheng lines. This caused the Song army to be defeated and Hua Yuan to be captured.

sentences.zh: 宋以兵車百乘文馬四百匹贖華元。

translations.literal: Song redeemed Hua Yuan with a hundred war chariots and four hundred fine horses.
translations.idiomatic: Song ransomed Hua Yuan with a hundred war chariots and four hundred fine horses.

sentences.zh: 未盡入，華元亡歸宋。

translations.literal: They had not completely entered. Hua Yuan fled and returned to Song.
translations.idiomatic: Before the ransom was fully delivered, Hua Yuan escaped and returned to Song.

sentences.zh: 十四年，楚莊王圍鄭。

translations.literal: In the fourteenth year, Chu's King Zhuang surrounded Zheng.
translations.idiomatic: In the fourteenth year, King Zhuang of Chu besieged Zheng.

sentences.zh: 鄭伯降楚，楚復釋之。

translations.literal: Duke Zheng surrendered to Chu. Chu again released him.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Zheng surrendered to Chu. Chu released him once more.

sentences.zh: 十六年，楚使過宋，宋有前仇，執楚使。

translations.literal: In the sixteenth year, a Chu envoy passed through Song. Song had previous enmity and seized the Chu envoy.
translations.idiomatic: In the sixteenth year, a Chu envoy passed through Song. Due to past grievances, Song detained the Chu envoy.

sentences.zh: 九月，楚莊王圍宋。

translations.literal: In the ninth month, Chu's King Zhuang surrounded Song.
translations.idiomatic: In the ninth month, King Zhuang of Chu besieged Song.

sentences.zh: 十七年，楚以圍宋五月不解，宋城中急，無食，華元乃夜私見楚將子反。

translations.literal: In the seventeenth year, Chu, because they had besieged Song for five months without releasing it, the Song city was urgent with no food. Hua Yuan then at night privately saw the Chu general Zi Fan.
translations.idiomatic: In the seventeenth year, Chu had besieged Song for five months without lifting the siege. The city of Song was in dire straits with no food remaining. Hua Yuan secretly met with the Chu general Zi Fan under cover of night.

sentences.zh: 子反告莊王。

translations.literal: Zi Fan told King Zhuang.
translations.idiomatic: Zi Fan reported this to King Zhuang.

sentences.zh: 王問：「城中何如？」

translations.literal: Wang asked: 'City middle what like?'
translations.idiomatic: The wang asked: 'What is it like in the city?'

sentences.zh: 曰：「析骨而炊，易子而食。」

translations.literal: Said: 'Split bones and cook, exchange children and eat.'
translations.idiomatic: He said: 'They split bones and cook, exchange children and eat.'

sentences.zh: 莊王曰：「誠哉言！

translations.literal: Zhuang Wang said: 'Truly words!'
translations.idiomatic: King Zhuang said: 'Truly the words!'

sentences.zh: 我軍亦有二日糧。」

translations.literal: Our army also has two days grain.'
translations.idiomatic: Our army also has two days' grain.'

sentences.zh: 以信故，遂罷兵去。

translations.literal: Because of sincerity, they then stopped the troops and left.
translations.idiomatic: Moved by this demonstration of sincerity, they withdrew their troops and departed.

sentences.zh: 二十二年，文公卒，子共公瑕立。

translations.literal: In the twenty-second year, Duke Wen died, and his son Duke Gong Xia ascended.
translations.idiomatic: In the twenty-second year, Duke Wen passed away, and his son Xia ascended the throne as Duke Gong.

sentences.zh: 始厚葬。

translations.literal: They began thick burials.
translations.idiomatic: This marked the beginning of elaborate burials.

sentences.zh: 君子譏華元不臣矣。

translations.literal: The gentleman criticized Hua Yuan for not being a minister.
translations.idiomatic: The noble-minded criticized Hua Yuan for lacking the proper demeanor of a minister.

sentences.zh: 共公（元）［十］年，華元善楚將子重，又善晉將欒書，兩盟晉楚。

translations.literal: In Duke Gong's tenth year, Hua Yuan was good with Chu's general Zi Zhong, and also good with Jin's general Luan Shu. He allied both Jin and Chu.
translations.idiomatic: In Duke Gong's tenth year, Hua Yuan maintained good relations with Chu's general Zi Zhong and also with Jin's general Luan Shu. He forged alliances with both Jin and Chu.

sentences.zh: 十三年，共公卒。

translations.literal: In the thirteenth year, Duke Gong died.
translations.idiomatic: In the thirteenth year, Duke Gong passed away.

sentences.zh: 華元為右師，魚石為左師。

translations.literal: Hua Yuan served as right teacher, Yu Shi served as left teacher.
translations.idiomatic: Hua Yuan became the Right Minister, and Yu Shi became the Left Minister.

sentences.zh: 司馬唐山攻殺太子肥，欲殺華元，華元奔晉，魚石止之，至河乃還，誅唐山。

translations.literal: Si Ma Tang Shan attacked and killed Crown Prince Fei. He desired to kill Hua Yuan. Hua Yuan fled to Jin. Yu Shi stopped him. He reached the river and then returned. They executed Tang Shan.
translations.idiomatic: The Marshal Tang Shan attacked and assassinated Crown Prince Fei. He then sought to kill Hua Yuan. Hua Yuan fled to Jin, but Yu Shi intercepted him. When they reached the river, Hua Yuan turned back. They executed Tang Shan.

sentences.zh: 乃立共公少子成，是為平公。

translations.literal: They then established Duke Gong's young son Cheng, who became Duke Ping.
translations.idiomatic: They then installed Duke Gong's youngest son Cheng as ruler, who became Duke Ping.

sentences.zh: 平公三年，楚共王拔宋之彭城，以封宋左師魚石。

translations.literal: In Duke Ping's third year, Chu's King Gong seized Song's Peng Cheng to enfeoff Song's left teacher Yu Shi.
translations.idiomatic: In Duke Ping's third year, King Gong of Chu captured Song's Pengcheng and granted it as a fief to Song's Left Minister Yu Shi.

sentences.zh: 四年，諸侯共誅魚石，而歸彭城於宋。

translations.literal: In the fourth year, the feudal lords together executed Yu Shi and returned Peng Cheng to Song.
translations.idiomatic: In the fourth year, the feudal lords united to execute Yu Shi and restored Pengcheng to Song.

sentences.zh: 三十五年，楚公子圍弒其君自立，為靈王。

translations.literal: In the thirty-fifth year, Chu's Prince Wei assassinated his lord and self-established as King Ling.
translations.idiomatic: In the thirty-fifth year, Prince Wei of Chu assassinated his ruler and usurped the throne as King Ling.

sentences.zh: 四十四年，平公卒，子元公佐立。

translations.literal: In the forty-fourth year, Duke Ping died, and his son Duke Yuan Zuo ascended.
translations.idiomatic: In the forty-fourth year, Duke Ping passed away, and his son Zuo ascended the throne as Duke Yuan.

sentences.zh: 元公三年，楚公子棄疾弒靈王，自立為平王。

translations.literal: In Duke Yuan's third year, Chu's Prince Qi Ji assassinated King Ling and self-established as King Ping.
translations.idiomatic: In Duke Yuan's third year, Prince Qi Ji of Chu assassinated King Ling and usurped the throne as King Ping.

sentences.zh: 八年，宋火。

translations.literal: In the eighth year, Song had a fire.
translations.idiomatic: In the eighth year, Song suffered a major fire.

sentences.zh: 十年，元公毋信，詐殺諸公子，大夫華、向氏作亂。

translations.literal: In the tenth year, Duke Yuan had no trust. He falsely killed the various princes. The grand officers of the Hua and Xiang clans made rebellion.
translations.idiomatic: In the tenth year, Duke Yuan became untrustworthy. He falsely accused and executed the various princes. The grand officers of the Hua and Xiang clans rose in rebellion.

sentences.zh: 楚平王太子建來奔，見諸華氏相攻亂，建去如鄭。

translations.literal: Chu's King Ping's crown prince Jian came fleeing. He saw the various Hua clans mutually attacking in chaos. Jian left and went to Zheng.
translations.idiomatic: Crown Prince Jian of King Ping of Chu came fleeing as a refugee. He witnessed the Hua clans attacking each other in chaos. Jian departed and went to Zheng.

sentences.zh: 十五年，元公為魯昭公避季氏居外，為之求入魯，行道卒，子景公頭曼立。

translations.literal: In the fifteenth year, Duke Yuan, for Lu's Duke Zhao, avoided the Ji clan and resided outside. He sought for him to enter Lu. Traveling on the road, he died. His son Duke Jing Tou Man ascended.
translations.idiomatic: In the fifteenth year, Duke Yuan went into exile on behalf of Duke Zhao of Lu to escape the Ji clan. He sought to help Duke Zhao return to Lu. While traveling, he died on the road. His son Tou Man ascended the throne as Duke Jing.

sentences.zh: 景公十六年，魯陽虎來奔，已復去。

translations.literal: In Duke Jing's sixteenth year, Lu's Yang Hu came fleeing, then again left.
translations.idiomatic: In Duke Jing's sixteenth year, Yang Hu of Lu came fleeing as a refugee, but soon departed again.

sentences.zh: 二十五年，孔子過宋，宋司馬桓魋惡之，欲殺孔子，孔子微服去。

translations.literal: In the twenty-fifth year, Kong Qiu passed through Song. Song's Si Ma Huan Dai hated him and desired to kill Kong Qiu. Kong Qiu disguised himself and left.
translations.idiomatic: In the twenty-fifth year, Confucius passed through Song. The Song marshal Huan Dai hated him and sought to assassinate him. Confucius disguised himself in humble clothing and departed.

sentences.zh: 三十年，曹倍宋，又倍晉，宋伐曹，晉不救，遂滅曹有之。

translations.literal: In the thirtieth year, Cao betrayed Song, and again betrayed Jin. Song attacked Cao. Jin did not save them. Song then extinguished Cao and possessed it.
translations.idiomatic: In the thirtieth year, Cao betrayed Song and then also betrayed Jin. Song attacked Cao. Jin refused to come to their aid. Song then conquered Cao and annexed it.

sentences.zh: 三十六年，齊田常弒簡公。

translations.literal: In the thirty-sixth year, Qi's Tian Chang assassinated Duke Jian.
translations.idiomatic: In the thirty-sixth year, Tian Chang of Qi assassinated Duke Jian.

sentences.zh: 三十七年，楚惠王滅陳。

translations.literal: In the thirty-seventh year, Chu's King Hui extinguished Chen.
translations.idiomatic: In the thirty-seventh year, King Hui of Chu conquered Chen.

sentences.zh: 熒惑守心。

translations.literal: Ying Huo guarded Xin.
translations.idiomatic: The planet Mars stationed at the Heart asterism.

sentences.zh: 心，宋之分野也。

translations.literal: Xin is Song's celestial region.
translations.idiomatic: The Heart asterism corresponds to Song's territory.

sentences.zh: 景公憂之。

translations.literal: Duke Jing worried about it.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Jing became anxious about this omen.

sentences.zh: 司星子韋曰：「可移於相。」

translations.literal: Si Xing Zi Wei said: 'Can move to prime minister.'
translations.idiomatic: The Si Xing Zi Wei said: 'Can move it to the prime minister.'

sentences.zh: 景公曰：「相，吾之股肱。」

translations.literal: Jing Gong said: 'Prime minister, my limbs.'
translations.idiomatic: Duke Jing said: 'The prime minister is my limbs.'

sentences.zh: 曰：「可移於民。」

translations.literal: Said: 'Can move to people.'
translations.idiomatic: He said: 'Can move it to the people.'

sentences.zh: 景公曰：「君者待民。」

translations.literal: Jing Gong said: 'Lord relies on people.'
translations.idiomatic: Duke Jing said: 'A lord relies on the people.'

sentences.zh: 曰：「可移於歲。」

translations.literal: Said: 'Can move to year.'
translations.idiomatic: He said: 'Can move it to the year.'

sentences.zh: 景公曰：「歲饑民困，吾誰為君！」

translations.literal: Jing Gong said: 'Year famine people distressed, I for whom be lord!'
translations.idiomatic: Duke Jing said: 'The year has famine and the people are distressed. For whom would I be lord!'

sentences.zh: 子韋曰：「天高聽卑。

translations.literal: Zi Wei said: 'Heaven high hears low.
translations.idiomatic: Zi Wei said: 'Heaven is high and hears the low.

sentences.zh: 君有君人之言三，熒惑宜有動。」

translations.literal: Lord has lord people words three, Ying Huo should have movement.'
translations.idiomatic: The lord has three words of a lord over people. Ying Huo should have movement.'

sentences.zh: 於是候之，果徙三度。

translations.literal: They then observed it, and indeed it moved three degrees.
translations.idiomatic: They then observed it closely, and indeed it moved three degrees.

sentences.zh: 六十四年，景公卒。

translations.literal: In the sixty-fourth year, Duke Jing died.
translations.idiomatic: In the sixty-fourth year, Duke Jing passed away.

sentences.zh: 宋公子特攻殺太子而自立，是為昭公。

translations.literal: Song's Prince Te attacked and killed the crown prince and self-established, who became Duke Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: Prince Te of Song attacked and assassinated the crown prince, then usurped the throne for himself and became Duke Zhao.

sentences.zh: 昭公者，元公之曾庶孫也。

translations.literal: Duke Zhao was Duke Yuan's great-grandson from a concubine.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Zhao was a great-grandson of Duke Yuan through a concubine.

sentences.zh: 昭公父公孫糾，糾父公子褍秦，褍秦即元公少子也。

translations.literal: Duke Zhao's father was Gong Sun Jiu. Jiu's father was Prince Ju Qin. Ju Qin was Duke Yuan's young son.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Zhao's father was Gong Sun Jiu. Jiu's father was Prince Ju Qin. Ju Qin was Duke Yuan's youngest son.

sentences.zh: 景公殺昭公父糾，故昭公怨殺太子而自立。

translations.literal: Duke Jing killed Duke Zhao's father Jiu. Therefore Duke Zhao resented it, killed the crown prince, and self-established.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Jing had killed Duke Zhao's father Jiu. Therefore Duke Zhao, harboring resentment, assassinated the crown prince and usurped the throne for himself.

sentences.zh: 昭公四十七年卒，子悼公購由立。

translations.literal: Duke Zhao died in his forty-seventh year, and his son Duke Dao Gou You ascended.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Zhao died in his forty-seventh year of rule. His son Gou You ascended the throne as Duke Dao.

sentences.zh: 悼公八年卒，子休公田立。

translations.literal: Duke Dao died in his eighth year, and his son Duke Xiu Tian ascended.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Dao died in his eighth year of rule. His son Tian ascended the throne as Duke Xiu.

sentences.zh: 休公田二十三年卒，子辟公辟兵立。

translations.literal: Duke Xiu Tian died in his twenty-third year, and his son Duke Bi Bi Bing ascended.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Xiu Tian died in his twenty-third year of rule. His son Bi Bing ascended the throne as Duke Bi.

sentences.zh: 辟公三年卒，子剔成立。

translations.literal: Duke Bi died in his third year, and his son Ti Cheng ascended.
translations.idiomatic: Duke Bi died in his third year of rule. His son Ti Cheng ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 剔成四十一年，剔成弟偃攻襲剔成，剔成敗奔齊，偃自立為宋君。

translations.literal: In Ti Cheng's forty-first year, Ti Cheng's younger brother Yan attacked and raided Ti Cheng. Ti Cheng was defeated and fled to Qi. Yan self-established as Song's lord.
translations.idiomatic: In the forty-first year of Ti Cheng's rule, his younger brother Yan attacked and overthrew him. Ti Cheng was defeated and fled to Qi. Yan usurped the throne and became lord of Song.

sentences.zh: 君偃十一年，自立為王。

translations.literal: In Lord Yan's eleventh year, he self-established as wang.
translations.idiomatic: In the eleventh year of Lord Yan's rule, he proclaimed himself king.

sentences.zh: 東敗齊，取五城；

translations.literal: East defeated Qi, took five cities;
translations.idiomatic: In the east he defeated Qi and took five cities;

sentences.zh: 南敗楚，取地三百里；

translations.literal: South defeated Chu, took land three hundred li;
translations.idiomatic: In the south he defeated Chu and took land three hundred li;

sentences.zh: 西敗魏軍，乃與齊、魏為敵國。

translations.literal: In the west he defeated Wei's army, and then became an enemy state with Qi and Wei.
translations.idiomatic: In the west he defeated Wei's army, and thus became enemies with both Qi and Wei.

sentences.zh: 盛血以韋囊，縣而射之，命曰「射天」。

translations.literal: Filled blood with leather bag, hung and shot it, named 'shoot heaven'.
translations.idiomatic: He filled a leather bag with blood, hung it and shot it, naming it 'shoot heaven'.

sentences.zh: 淫於酒婦人。

translations.literal: He was licentious with wine and women.
translations.idiomatic: He indulged in wine and women.

sentences.zh: 群臣諫者輒射之。

translations.literal: The multitude of ministers who admonished—he then shot them.
translations.idiomatic: He shot any minister who dared to admonish him.

sentences.zh: 於是諸侯皆曰「桀宋」。

translations.literal: Then feudal lords all said 'Jie Song'.
translations.idiomatic: Then all the feudal lords said 'Jie Song'.

sentences.zh: 「宋其復為紂所為，不可不誅」。

translations.literal: 'Song will again do what Zhou did, cannot not execute.'
translations.idiomatic: 'Song will again do what Zhou did. It cannot but be executed.'

sentences.zh: 告齊伐宋。

translations.literal: They informed Qi to attack Song.
translations.idiomatic: They appealed to Qi to attack Song.

sentences.zh: 王偃立四十七年，齊湣王與魏、楚伐宋，殺王偃，遂滅宋而三分其地。

translations.literal: Wang Yan ascended for forty-seven years. Qi's King Min with Wei and Chu attacked Song, killed Wang Yan, then extinguished Song and divided its land into three.
translations.idiomatic: King Yan ruled for forty-seven years. King Min of Qi, together with Wei and Chu, attacked Song, killed King Yan, and conquered Song, dividing its territory among the three states.

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：孔子稱「微子去之，箕子為之奴，比干諫而死，殷有三仁焉」。

translations.literal: Grand Historian said: Kong Qiu praised 'Wei Zi left it, Ji Zi became slave for it, Bi Gan admonished and died, Yin had three benevolent.'
translations.idiomatic: The Grand Historian said: Kong Qiu praised 'Wei Zi left it, Ji Zi became a slave for it, Bi Gan admonished and died. Yin had three benevolent men.'

sentences.zh: 春秋譏宋之亂自宣公廢太子而立弟，國以不寧者十世。

translations.literal: The Spring and Autumn Annals criticized Song's chaos from Duke Xuan deposing the crown prince and establishing his younger brother. The state was not peaceful for ten generations.
translations.idiomatic: The Spring and Autumn Annals criticizes how Song's chaos began when Duke Xuan deposed the crown prince and installed his younger brother instead. The state knew no peace for ten generations.

sentences.zh: 襄公之時，修行仁義，欲為盟主。

translations.literal: In Duke Xiang's time, he practiced benevolence and righteousness and desired to be the alliance leader.
translations.idiomatic: During Duke Xiang's time, he cultivated benevolence and righteousness, aspiring to become the leader of the alliance.

sentences.zh: 其大夫正考父美之，故追道契、湯、高宗，殷所以興，作商頌。

translations.literal: His grand officer Zheng Kao Fu praised it, therefore traced the way of Jie, Tang, Gao Zong—why Yin rose—and made the Shang Song.
translations.idiomatic: His grand officer Zheng Kaofu praised this virtue. Therefore he traced the ways of Jie, Tang, and Gaozong—the reasons Yin prospered—and composed the Shang Hymns.

sentences.zh: 襄公既敗於泓，而君子或以為多，傷中國闕禮義，褒之也，宋襄之有禮讓也。

translations.literal: Duke Xiang was already defeated at Hong, and some gentlemen considered it excessive, hurt China for lacking ritual and righteousness. They praised it—Song Xiang's having ritual and yielding.
translations.idiomatic: Though Duke Xiang was defeated at the Hong River, some gentlemen considered his conduct excessive. They were pained that China lacked ritual and righteousness, yet praised him for possessing the virtues of courtesy and yielding that characterized Song Xiang.
